subtitle: 1 00:02:00,455 --> 00:02:01,956 Carol... 2 00:02:03,833 --> 00:02:05,293 Mr. Vice-President... 3 00:02:05,752 --> 00:02:07,795 Mind your manners. 4 00:02:08,880 --> 00:02:11,702 Sorry! I got carried away. 5 00:02:11,702 --> 00:02:13,635 What were you doing? 6 00:02:15,219 --> 00:02:18,292 I was thinking about this story. 7 00:02:18,292 --> 00:02:19,974 Story? 8 00:02:19,974 --> 00:02:26,928 Yes. The series of strange tales that began in November 1930. 9 00:02:26,928 --> 00:02:32,570 We once traveled together on a train, didn't we, Carol? 10 00:02:33,321 --> 00:02:38,159 Do you remember what I told you back then? 11 00:02:38,701 --> 00:02:40,495 Let's see... 12 00:02:41,871 --> 00:02:44,332 Wow! A rainbow! 13 00:02:44,916 --> 00:02:46,084 Carol... 14 00:02:47,001 --> 00:02:50,282 Ever since we were children, we have thought of rainbows 15 00:02:50,282 --> 00:02:54,175 as beautiful things, without any doubt. 16 00:02:54,717 --> 00:02:56,427 Why is that? 17 00:02:57,595 --> 00:03:00,458 People who don't know about the refraction of light 18 00:03:00,458 --> 00:03:04,247 could also think of it as a harbinger of natural disaster. 19 00:03:04,247 --> 00:03:10,388 Something undesirable may be descending from that rainbow. 20 00:03:10,388 --> 00:03:15,279 The vegetation may be burning at the base of that rainbow. 21 00:03:17,240 --> 00:03:20,188 Why do we feel a fairy tale sensation 22 00:03:20,188 --> 00:03:23,942 from that small set of seven-color information? 23 00:03:23,942 --> 00:03:26,582 Have you ever thought about that? 24 00:03:27,166 --> 00:03:27,959 No. 25 00:03:28,668 --> 00:03:31,322 I mean, even if I had thought about it, I wouldn't know how to say it, 26 00:03:31,322 --> 00:03:35,078 and besides, our job isn't to think about things, 27 00:03:35,078 --> 00:03:37,802 but to report to others the result of what has already happened. 28 00:03:41,305 --> 00:03:42,807 319 points. 29 00:03:43,224 --> 00:03:45,252 Out of how many? 30 00:03:45,252 --> 00:03:50,537 It's true, our job is to convey the truth to others, 31 00:03:50,537 --> 00:03:56,182 but the moment we obtain any information, be it true or false, 32 00:03:56,182 --> 00:04:00,518 we must not stop thinking. We must not limit ourselves to merely determining 33 00:04:00,518 --> 00:04:03,358 whether the information is true or false. 34 00:04:03,358 --> 00:04:07,680 That is the responsibility of those who transmit information to others. 35 00:04:07,680 --> 00:04:10,960 But what is there to think about? 36 00:04:11,461 --> 00:04:15,687 Just thinking about something doesn't change whether it's true or not, right? 37 00:04:15,687 --> 00:04:17,842 Yes, it does change. 38 00:04:21,804 --> 00:04:24,252 Do you remember, Carol? 39 00:04:24,252 --> 00:04:26,343 Yes, Mr. Vice-President. 40 00:04:26,343 --> 00:04:31,945 A story is not information, nor is it accumulated information. 41 00:04:31,945 --> 00:04:34,348 It is the result of what was thought. 42 00:04:34,348 --> 00:04:42,492 Carol, why did you think these stories began in November 1930? 43 00:04:44,494 --> 00:04:45,704 Well... 44 00:04:45,704 --> 00:04:49,902 What's the matter, Carol? And you call yourself an assistant 45 00:04:49,902 --> 00:04:53,267 to Gustave Saint-Germain, Vice-President of the Daily Days? 46 00:04:53,267 --> 00:04:54,294 Well, I... 47 00:04:54,294 --> 00:04:56,631 Let's say, Carol... 48 00:05:01,928 --> 00:05:04,055 We are in 1711, 49 00:05:04,806 --> 00:05:11,729 and perhaps it would be better to start inside the Advenna Avis, as it crosses the Atlantic. 50 00:05:12,188 --> 00:05:14,263 Or, perhaps, 51 00:05:14,263 --> 00:05:17,558 it would be better to start with the unpleasant business 52 00:05:17,558 --> 00:05:21,642 that happened aboard the transcontinental Flying Pussyfoot, 53 00:05:21,642 --> 00:05:24,534 which was covered up. 54 00:05:26,118 --> 00:05:28,412 In any case, Carol, 55 00:05:28,955 --> 00:05:35,618 you chose November 1930 as the beginning of the story. 56 00:05:35,618 --> 00:05:37,658 Why? 57 00:05:37,658 --> 00:05:39,090 Mr. Vice-President, it's because... 58 00:05:40,550 --> 00:05:44,511 It's because, you see, I thought about what would be easiest to understand. 59 00:05:44,511 --> 00:05:49,617 It was at this point that these incidents first appeared before us. 60 00:05:49,617 --> 00:05:50,644 That's why. 61 00:05:50,644 --> 00:05:52,672 156 points. 62 00:05:52,672 --> 00:05:54,468 Out of how many? 63 00:05:54,468 --> 00:05:57,388 Indeed, it is easier to understand. 64 00:05:57,388 --> 00:05:58,587 But, Carol, 65 00:05:58,587 --> 00:06:01,837 you must think about more than just the timeline. 66 00:06:01,837 --> 00:06:04,031 The characters are also crucial. 67 00:06:04,407 --> 00:06:05,783 Let's say... 68 00:06:07,618 --> 00:06:08,452 Hey! 69 00:06:09,370 --> 00:06:11,080 Isaac! 70 00:06:11,414 --> 00:06:14,390 What if we looked at that eccentric pair of thieves 71 00:06:14,390 --> 00:06:16,878 as being the main characters? 72 00:06:17,336 --> 00:06:18,546 Or, perhaps, 73 00:06:19,922 --> 00:06:22,550 the young boy, suffering from a cursed fate? 74 00:06:27,930 --> 00:06:29,432 Or, perhaps, 75 00:06:32,602 --> 00:06:36,230 the young and brilliant capo of the Gandor Family? 76 00:06:36,814 --> 00:06:37,940 Or, perhaps... 77 00:06:38,274 --> 00:06:40,109 If that's what you mean... 78 00:06:42,278 --> 00:06:46,154 Charity? Please, do you have any charity to offer? 79 00:06:46,154 --> 00:06:48,887 The Lord is watching your actions. 80 00:06:48,887 --> 00:06:51,412 In time, the Lord will judge your actions... 81 00:06:53,831 --> 00:06:54,999 Old man... 82 00:06:57,209 --> 00:06:58,836 He seems like main character material. 83 00:06:59,378 --> 00:07:00,171 "Material"? 84 00:07:00,713 --> 00:07:02,548 Yes. "Material". 85 00:07:07,178 --> 00:07:09,180 I'm in a good mood today. 86 00:07:09,805 --> 00:07:10,848 Here. 87 00:07:12,642 --> 00:07:14,851 Thank you very much, sir! 88 00:07:14,851 --> 00:07:19,148 The Lord will surely bless your actions! 89 00:07:19,565 --> 00:07:23,722 Stop being so pious only when it suits you, old man. 90 00:07:23,722 --> 00:07:25,638 Just a moment, sir. 91 00:07:25,638 --> 00:07:27,865 I have some flowers I picked this morning, to thank you. 92 00:07:28,407 --> 00:07:30,570 They're probably wilted by now. 93 00:07:30,570 --> 00:07:34,580 I'm not so sure about that... sir! 94 00:07:35,706 --> 00:07:37,875 Well, he's quite close, isn't he? 95 00:08:02,608 --> 00:08:04,652 Say, tell me something... 96 00:08:05,528 --> 00:08:07,478 Get away from me, you monster! 97 00:08:07,478 --> 00:08:13,108 Did you know that I am Firo Prochainezo, of the Martillo Family, 98 00:08:13,108 --> 00:08:13,828 old man?! 99 00:08:18,332 --> 00:08:20,918 Now I understand! 100 00:08:21,752 --> 00:08:25,294 "Main character material." You may be right about that. 101 00:08:25,294 --> 00:08:26,257 Aren't I? 102 00:08:26,757 --> 00:08:30,498 Still, Carol, depending on whom you focus, 103 00:08:30,498 --> 00:08:34,598 the same incident changes shape in always variable ways. 104 00:08:35,224 --> 00:08:37,212 In other words, there is one incident, 105 00:08:37,212 --> 00:08:41,772 but there are as many stories about it as there are people involved. 106 00:09:09,383 --> 00:09:10,801 Attention, men! 107 00:09:11,218 --> 00:09:12,998 Destroy everything! 108 00:09:12,998 --> 00:09:15,128 No need for warnings or negotiations! 109 00:09:15,128 --> 00:09:17,843 Now it's our turn! 110 00:09:17,843 --> 00:09:22,508 No one else exists in our world! 111 00:09:22,508 --> 00:09:27,178 Gandors, Martillos, it doesn't matter! Crush them all until nothing remains! 112 00:09:27,178 --> 00:09:32,156 Make it look like they simply never existed! 113 00:09:37,119 --> 00:09:41,332 So, what happened to that idiot, Luck? 114 00:09:41,957 --> 00:09:44,187 Chick-san is taking care of him. 115 00:09:44,187 --> 00:09:47,546 He's seeing if there's still enough sensitivity left to feel pain. 116 00:09:50,925 --> 00:09:53,185 Boss, they got us again! 117 00:09:53,185 --> 00:09:54,543 What was the damage? 118 00:09:54,543 --> 00:09:57,145 A game room, a bar, and a ticket office. 119 00:09:57,145 --> 00:09:59,517 Luckily, no one died. 120 00:10:00,601 --> 00:10:04,355 Those Runoratas! I'll blow them all up! 121 00:10:04,355 --> 00:10:07,399 Finish them! Kill them all! 122 00:10:08,651 --> 00:10:12,363 We brought back one of the guys who went after the ticket office. 123 00:10:12,738 --> 00:10:14,156 Alright... 124 00:10:15,825 --> 00:10:20,371 So you're the bastard who came after our territory, huh?! 125 00:10:22,331 --> 00:10:24,708 You've got a lot of nerve, don't you? 126 00:10:28,337 --> 00:10:33,162 So you're saying it starts when the Mafia and the Camorra come into conflict? 127 00:10:33,162 --> 00:10:35,553 In one of the cases. 128 00:10:35,928 --> 00:10:38,708 Luck Gandor was put to sleep. 129 00:10:38,708 --> 00:10:42,685 They said he was quite capable, but it was child's play. 130 00:10:47,356 --> 00:10:49,567 The Gandors are a small-time group, after all. 131 00:10:50,192 --> 00:10:52,736 It won't take much work to eliminate them. 132 00:10:59,160 --> 00:11:03,692 We've already made arrangements to buy some newer special bombs from certain sources, 133 00:11:03,692 --> 00:11:06,278 so, in time, we'll also finish off the Martillos. 134 00:11:06,278 --> 00:11:10,629 Forget that. There's something I need you to do. 135 00:11:16,343 --> 00:11:18,137 Or, perhaps... 136 00:11:21,515 --> 00:11:22,600 Older brother Dallas... 137 00:11:23,601 --> 00:11:24,977 Where are you? 138 00:11:27,146 --> 00:11:29,928 Or perhaps, Carol, 139 00:11:29,928 --> 00:11:36,155 it wouldn't be so surprising if we were the ones at the beginning of this story. 140 00:11:37,698 --> 00:11:38,866 It can't be! 141 00:11:47,291 --> 00:11:49,835 Dallas Genoard. You know him, right? 142 00:11:50,252 --> 00:11:53,833 Yes. He is the second son of the Genoard family. 143 00:11:53,833 --> 00:11:57,202 He is the son of Raymond Genoard, whom you killed on your own, 144 00:11:57,202 --> 00:11:59,470 without my orders. 145 00:11:59,929 --> 00:12:03,502 Dallas Genoard is the younger brother of Geoffrey Genoard, 146 00:12:03,502 --> 00:12:06,393 whom you also killed on your own. Understand? 147 00:12:07,311 --> 00:12:10,147 Yes. So, what about Dallas? 148 00:12:10,648 --> 00:12:12,848 He contacted the office. 149 00:12:12,848 --> 00:12:17,518 He said it was you who killed his father and brother, Gustavo. 150 00:12:17,518 --> 00:12:19,365 He also says he has proof. 151 00:12:20,032 --> 00:12:24,831 T-That can't be right. I even paid off the court officials. 152 00:12:24,831 --> 00:12:26,288 There can't be any proof. 153 00:12:26,705 --> 00:12:29,166 Then how did Dallas mention your name? 154 00:12:30,209 --> 00:12:31,335 Well... 155 00:12:31,919 --> 00:12:33,408 Resolve this. 156 00:12:33,408 --> 00:12:36,158 Find him and bring him here. 157 00:12:36,158 --> 00:12:37,492 Y-Yes, sir. 158 00:12:37,492 --> 00:12:39,372 But what about the Gandors? 159 00:12:39,372 --> 00:12:43,082 Dallas has maximum priority. Find him as quickly as possible. 160 00:12:43,082 --> 00:12:44,265 Y-Yes, sir. 161 00:12:45,599 --> 00:12:48,978 Can I decide whether he comes back dead or alive? 162 00:12:50,145 --> 00:12:52,106 Dead or alive? 163 00:12:53,190 --> 00:12:54,775 Do as you wish. 164 00:13:02,324 --> 00:13:05,272 Attention, men! Get Dallas! 165 00:13:05,272 --> 00:13:08,608 Find that contemptible second son of the Genoards! 166 00:13:08,608 --> 00:13:10,124 Dead or alive! 167 00:13:10,874 --> 00:13:14,420 He will pay for making a fool of me, Gustavo, 168 00:13:14,420 --> 00:13:15,045 He will pay for making a fool of me, Gustavo, What a miserable man. 169 00:13:15,045 --> 00:13:15,170 What a miserable man. 170 00:13:15,170 --> 00:13:16,630 and of the entire Runorata Family! What a miserable man. 171 00:13:16,630 --> 00:13:17,464 and of the entire Runorata Family! 172 00:13:19,591 --> 00:13:21,093 Say something! 173 00:13:22,177 --> 00:13:25,848 Where's the courage you had when you attacked our territory?! 174 00:13:26,223 --> 00:13:29,143 You were ready to pay for this, weren't you?! 175 00:13:30,686 --> 00:13:33,803 "Ugghh"? Don't give me "ugghh"! 176 00:13:33,803 --> 00:13:35,899 I told you to say something! 177 00:13:41,697 --> 00:13:42,990 Why are you... 178 00:13:43,407 --> 00:13:45,955 You look like you've seen a ghost. 179 00:13:45,955 --> 00:13:49,371 You... should be dead... 180 00:13:49,705 --> 00:13:51,540 Chick-san! Chick-san! 181 00:13:52,666 --> 00:13:55,836 Yes? What is it, Luck-san? 182 00:13:58,005 --> 00:14:00,215 I need to ask you to do one more thing. 183 00:14:00,591 --> 00:14:02,067 Very well. 184 00:14:02,067 --> 00:14:05,888 But I haven't washed off the blood and grease from last time yet. 185 00:14:06,221 --> 00:14:09,933 So I think it's going to hurt a lot. 186 00:14:10,559 --> 00:14:11,769 Sorry about that. 187 00:14:14,313 --> 00:14:15,439 P-Please, wait! 188 00:14:16,231 --> 00:14:21,111 I'll tell you everything! I'll tell! Just don't let that monster near me! 189 00:14:21,445 --> 00:14:24,656 Who was it that turned me into a sieve? 190 00:14:33,374 --> 00:14:34,500 Luck... 191 00:14:35,501 --> 00:14:36,715 Firo... 192 00:14:36,715 --> 00:14:39,698 You look scary when you smile like that. 193 00:14:39,698 --> 00:14:41,131 What are you reading? 194 00:14:43,008 --> 00:14:47,471 "Thy soul shall find itself alone 195 00:14:48,097 --> 00:14:51,975 'Mid dark thoughts of the grey tomb-stone; 196 00:14:52,518 --> 00:14:55,382 Not one, of all the crowd, to pry 197 00:14:55,382 --> 00:14:59,233 Into thine hour of secrecy." 198 00:15:02,611 --> 00:15:05,739 Long ago, I was so afraid of this poem that I couldn't stand it. 199 00:15:06,115 --> 00:15:08,826 But now it's not like that anymore. 200 00:15:09,368 --> 00:15:11,653 Not since the incident a year ago. 201 00:15:11,653 --> 00:15:12,996 Why? 202 00:15:13,497 --> 00:15:15,692 Perhaps because, just as I lost any need to be afraid, 203 00:15:15,692 --> 00:15:18,794 I also lost any feeling of anxiety. 204 00:15:19,670 --> 00:15:21,171 Regarding death, I mean. 205 00:15:23,090 --> 00:15:25,634 Firo, don't you think so? 206 00:15:26,885 --> 00:15:27,553 No. 207 00:15:32,015 --> 00:15:33,392 Forget about it, please. 208 00:15:33,892 --> 00:15:35,450 In any case, 209 00:15:35,450 --> 00:15:38,968 there has been an unusual group circling our territory lately. 210 00:15:38,968 --> 00:15:42,484 Probably some guys who have the Runoratas as backup. 211 00:15:42,818 --> 00:15:45,654 I'll be there to help you, when things get ugly. 212 00:15:45,988 --> 00:15:49,165 Firo, please pretend you don't know. 213 00:15:49,165 --> 00:15:50,868 This is our problem. 214 00:15:51,410 --> 00:15:53,557 That's asking for quite a lot. 215 00:15:53,557 --> 00:15:56,597 I won't leave the Martillos out of this. 216 00:15:56,597 --> 00:16:00,127 Don't worry. We called Vino. 217 00:16:01,003 --> 00:16:04,089 Vino? Claire is coming? 218 00:16:04,631 --> 00:16:08,469 Arriving on the Flying Pussyfoot tomorrow. 219 00:16:08,969 --> 00:16:11,918 In that case, Isaac and Miria are on the same train. 220 00:16:11,918 --> 00:16:15,117 One of Maiza-san's old friends is also on board. 221 00:16:15,117 --> 00:16:17,478 So, let's go pick them up together— 222 00:16:39,750 --> 00:16:40,834 And you're sure? 223 00:16:41,335 --> 00:16:43,988 Yes. The damage is severe, 224 00:16:43,988 --> 00:16:47,453 but there's no doubt they were passengers aboard the Flying Pussyfoot. 225 00:16:47,453 --> 00:16:49,305 How many bodies does that make? 226 00:16:49,305 --> 00:16:52,083 The number we've found is around a dozen. 227 00:16:52,083 --> 00:16:56,725 They were left along the tracks here and there for several dozen kilometers. 228 00:16:58,602 --> 00:17:02,303 Inspectors, what the hell happened here? 229 00:17:02,303 --> 00:17:04,303 The matter is confidential. 230 00:17:04,303 --> 00:17:06,151 It's better you don't know. 231 00:17:14,993 --> 00:17:17,295 It seems they were on board, yes. 232 00:17:17,295 --> 00:17:19,331 Immortals? 233 00:17:19,748 --> 00:17:20,791 Yes. 234 00:17:20,791 --> 00:17:24,336 Their names were on the passenger list at Chicago station. 235 00:17:24,920 --> 00:17:27,005 And what about the woman's safety? 236 00:17:27,381 --> 00:17:30,634 Our orders are to investigate that next. 237 00:17:33,220 --> 00:17:37,140 Do you think we can keep an incident like this covered up? 238 00:17:37,724 --> 00:17:39,142 Inspector Sullivan... 239 00:17:41,144 --> 00:17:42,396 What? 240 00:17:42,813 --> 00:17:45,482 There seems to be a survivor among the passengers who fell. 241 00:17:45,983 --> 00:17:47,234 What?! 242 00:18:04,084 --> 00:18:06,057 L-Luck-san... 243 00:18:06,057 --> 00:18:08,282 Hey. Are you hurt? 244 00:18:08,282 --> 00:18:12,676 Y-You just took several bullets! 245 00:18:16,305 --> 00:18:20,002 It's no problem, right? 246 00:18:20,002 --> 00:18:21,771 Hey! 247 00:18:21,771 --> 00:18:22,519 Huh? 248 00:18:22,978 --> 00:18:24,438 It doesn't hurt. 249 00:18:27,232 --> 00:18:30,678 Isaac! Your wound disappeared! 250 00:18:30,678 --> 00:18:32,472 That's an amazing trick! 251 00:18:32,472 --> 00:18:34,531 Maybe pigeons will appear next! 252 00:18:54,468 --> 00:18:56,053 He's so useless. 253 00:19:10,067 --> 00:19:13,612 There's no way you can still be alive... 254 00:19:15,697 --> 00:19:16,573 Firo! 255 00:19:17,866 --> 00:19:19,076 Firo, where are you?! 256 00:19:19,451 --> 00:19:20,827 Right here. 257 00:19:21,536 --> 00:19:22,245 This can't be! 258 00:19:26,166 --> 00:19:28,210 At least let me do this. 259 00:19:31,004 --> 00:19:32,506 I'll pay for the damages. 260 00:19:33,382 --> 00:19:34,952 So, what you saw here today... 261 00:19:34,952 --> 00:19:36,947 N-No, not at all! 262 00:19:36,947 --> 00:19:38,929 I didn't see anything! 263 00:19:39,638 --> 00:19:44,133 Besides, if I told anyone, they'd put me in an asylum, at the very least! 264 00:19:44,133 --> 00:19:45,143 Even so... 265 00:19:46,061 --> 00:19:48,605 it doesn't seem like we can ignore this. 266 00:19:51,483 --> 00:19:53,110 I will find you. 267 00:19:53,777 --> 00:19:55,112 I promise. 268 00:20:07,833 --> 00:20:11,675 The Flying Pussyfoot is quite an unusual train, isn't it? 269 00:20:11,675 --> 00:20:16,118 I've seen it once before and, in a way, it's excessively ornamental. 270 00:20:16,118 --> 00:20:19,400 If I had to say, it seems rather ostentatious. 271 00:20:19,400 --> 00:20:21,332 Now I want to see it even more. 272 00:20:21,332 --> 00:20:22,973 What a shame. 273 00:20:24,891 --> 00:20:28,088 There was an announcement a while ago that the Flying Pussyfoot had a breakdown, 274 00:20:28,088 --> 00:20:31,314 and all passenger cars were transferred to another train. 275 00:20:31,857 --> 00:20:33,817 What?! Are you serious?! 276 00:20:34,401 --> 00:20:37,518 In any case, the front car will be replaced by an electric locomotive, 277 00:20:37,518 --> 00:20:41,852 smoke-free, before entering Manhattan, 278 00:20:41,852 --> 00:20:44,550 so you won't be able to see everything. 279 00:20:44,550 --> 00:20:46,496 Maybe, but... 280 00:20:47,247 --> 00:20:53,253 Oh, by the way, what kind of person is this old friend of yours, Maiza-san? 281 00:20:53,628 --> 00:20:55,005 Ah, yes... 282 00:20:55,797 --> 00:21:00,538 He tries to carry everything on his shoulders, despite being so introverted. 283 00:21:00,538 --> 00:21:02,657 That's the kind of person he is. 284 00:21:02,657 --> 00:21:05,752 The type who wouldn't last long, if he were a normal person, right? 285 00:21:05,752 --> 00:21:08,962 Claire is the same way, for the opposite reason. 286 00:21:08,962 --> 00:21:11,188 Cheerful, but too stubborn. 287 00:21:11,605 --> 00:21:12,898 That's the truth. 288 00:21:14,983 --> 00:21:16,693 Hey, hey, hey, hey, hey! 289 00:21:17,277 --> 00:21:21,693 Are you going to decide whether to just stare at me or take me away? 290 00:21:21,693 --> 00:21:24,910 Despite appearances, I'm in a terrible mood. 291 00:21:28,997 --> 00:21:33,251 If I had known this would happen, I would have killed you sooner. 292 00:21:33,835 --> 00:21:37,547 Or would you prefer I kill you right here? 293 00:21:37,923 --> 00:21:39,841 But, Ladd... 294 00:21:40,175 --> 00:21:41,885 What? 295 00:21:41,885 --> 00:21:45,013 Are you saying you don't want to be killed by me?! 296 00:22:00,779 --> 00:22:04,533 That hurts! It hurts! Just a minute... 297 00:22:05,450 --> 00:22:09,913 Sorry, Nice... Please, can we go a little slower? 298 00:22:15,794 --> 00:22:16,670 Hey! 299 00:22:18,588 --> 00:22:19,923 Hey, you there! 300 00:22:23,385 --> 00:22:27,054 Oh! Ennis, Firo, and Maiza! 301 00:22:27,054 --> 00:22:29,554 Long time no see, my dear friends! 302 00:22:29,554 --> 00:22:31,685 I'm so happy to see that everyone is doing so well! 303 00:22:32,060 --> 00:22:33,957 You too, Isaac-san and Miria-san. 304 00:22:33,957 --> 00:22:34,521 We're fine! 305 00:22:34,521 --> 00:22:35,272 We're fine! What happened? You look like a wreck— 306 00:22:35,272 --> 00:22:37,566 What happened? You look like a wreck— 307 00:22:38,233 --> 00:22:41,444 Live a long life, and I'll tell you someday! 308 00:22:42,404 --> 00:22:44,531 It's been too long! 309 00:22:57,586 --> 00:23:07,585 Gazing at the starry sky that extends forever, we sing 310 00:23:11,808 --> 00:23:21,807 a melody of a dream that we have from our limited eternity 311 00:23:26,323 --> 00:23:33,358 The water of worship, overflowing in our hearts 312 00:23:33,358 --> 00:23:40,322 will reach someone in a distant future 313 00:23:40,322 --> 00:23:47,458 I believe this 314 00:23:47,458 --> 00:23:54,548 Running through the prolonged time, 315 00:23:54,548 --> 00:24:02,012 our calling voices will one day become a great song 316 00:24:02,012 --> 00:24:08,728 We can continue spinning our love 317 00:24:08,728 --> 00:24:18,781 even if now it is but such a small light 318 00:24:25,507 --> 00:24:28,341 Hey, Miria, where do you think this "outside" place is? 319 00:24:28,341 --> 00:24:29,971 You mean it's not at home, right? 320 00:24:29,971 --> 00:24:32,141 Which means it's somewhere that's not at home, right? 321 00:24:32,141 --> 00:24:33,641 So, where is this "somewhere"? 322 00:24:33,641 --> 00:24:36,184 I'm sure it's next door, where the old lady's worries are. 323 00:24:36,184 --> 00:24:39,980 That's amazing, Isaac! You're so smart!
